title: QUESTIONS.
text:

library(tidyverse)

Football_data <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs1124.csv")


Rows: 22010 Columns: 55

$ DefInterceptions  <dbl> 1, 0, 4, 3, 2, 2, 3, 2, 1, 1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1…
$ DefTotalTurnovers <dbl> 2, 1, 6, 4, 4, 3, 4, 5, 2, 3, 3, 5, 2, 2, 2, 1, 3, 1…
$ Team              <chr> "Oklahoma State", "Oklahoma State", "Oklahoma State"…
$ Conference        <chr> "Big 12 Conference", "Big 12 Conference", "Big 12 Co…
$ Season            <dbl> 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011…


Question: How do total penalty yards per game for college football teams correlate with their likelihood of winning, and how do factors like turnovers, opponent strength, or home/away status affect this relationship?
Does the data alreadt exist? Can you get it? Yes, game by game college football data is avaliable from NCAA Stats, ESPN, and Sports Reference, including penalty yars, points scored, turnovers, and game outcomes
Do you need assistance getting it? Potentially if using tables is needed. Otherwise, CSV downloads are avaliable
Time frame needed: The last five seasons (2019-2025) to capture recent trends
Will you need to improve or augment the data? Yes, I may need to combine multiple sources, and use that to identify penalties, points, and turnovers in columns.
Other examples: Sports blogs examine penalties, turnovers, and win probability like Football Outsiders, The Last Man Analytics and The Extra Point.


Code
Football_data |> 
  group_by(Opponent) |> 
summarise(Game = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(Game))


# A tibble: 388 × 2
   Opponent             Game
   <chr>               <int>
 1 Texas                 165
 2 Notre Dame            164
 3 Ohio State            164
 4 Southern California   164
 5 Michigan              163
 6 Oklahoma              162
 7 Alabama               161
 8 Boise State           161
 9 UCLA                  161
10 Clemson               160
# ℹ 378 more rows




Code
Football_data |> 
  group_by(Outcome) |> 
  summarise(Game = n())


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  Outcome  Game
  <chr>   <int>
1 L       10382
2 W       11628




Code
Football_data |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = Outcome, fill = Outcome)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Game Outcomes",
       x = "Outcome",
       y = "Number of Games") +
  theme_minimal()









A challenge I encountered is that the dataset doesn’t include consistent formatting and is missing thr values for team names and other stats. Additionally, because the data is only data from games, I may need to merge it with another data set to answer a broader question.


Code
library(tidyverse)

attendance <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/attendance.csv")


Rows: 146 Columns: 14
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (2): Institution, Conference
dbl (12): 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, ...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Big Ten CFB Avg Plays
text:
Big Ten Teams Are Running Fewer Plays After NCAA Clock Change


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(scales)



Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor


Code
CFB24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
CFB25 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
big_ten <- c("Illinois
", "Indiana", "Iowa", "Maryland", "Michigan", "Michigan State
", "Minnesota
", "Nebraska", "Northwestern", "Ohio State", "Penn State", "Purdue", "Rutgers", "Wisconsin")

bigten24 <- CFB24 |> 
  filter(Opponent%in%big_ten)

bigten25 <- CFB25 |> 
  filter(Opponent%in%big_ten)




Code
avg_plays_24 <- bigten24 |> 
  group_by(Opponent) |> 
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))

avg_plays_25 <- bigten25 |> 
  group_by(Opponent) |> 
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_24, 
    aes(
      x = reorder(Opponent, -avg_plays),
      weight = avg_plays
    )) +
      scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Offensive Plays by Opponent (2024 Season)",
    x = "Opponent",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()












Code
library(scales)




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_24, 
    aes(
      x = reorder(Opponent, -avg_plays),
      weight = avg_plays
    )) +
      scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Offensive Plays by Opponent (2024 Season)",
    x = "Opponent",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()













Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_25 , 
    aes(
      x = reorder(Opponent, -avg_plays),
      weight = avg_plays
    )) +
      scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Offensive Plays by Opponent (2025 Season)",
    x = "Opponent",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()









The data shows that most Big Ten teams are running fewer offensive plays per game in 2025 rather than in 2024, supporting the idea that the NCAA’s new timing rule that keeps the clock running after first downs, has shortened possessions. Maryland was the only team that saw a significant increase, most likely reflecting their upbeat offensive style. Overall, the rule change seems to have slightly reduced the pace of plays across the conference.

title: Post With Code
text: This is a post with executable code.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Where Do Students Go At Halfitme
text: It was halftime at SECU Stadium, and the crowd was quiet

title: Big Ten CFB Avg Plays
text:
Code
options(repos = c(CRAN = "https://cloud.r-project.org/"))
install.packages("cfbfastR")



The downloaded binary packages are in
    /var/folders/hb/mj10y4391xv219r79__kmdch0000gn/T//Rtmp35Fvab/downloaded_packages

Code
library(cfbfastR)




Code
library(cfbfastR)
library(tidyverse)

pbp_data <- load_cfb_pbp (seasons = 2021 :2025)  
third_and_six <- pbp_data |> 
  filter(down == 3, distance == 6)




Code
play_type <- third_and_six |> 
  group_by(play_type) |> 
  summarise(count = n()) |> 
  arrange(desc(count))




Code
run_plays <- third_and_six |> 
  filter(play_type == "Rush")




Code
num_run_plays <-nrow(run_plays)
total_third_and_six <- nrow(third_and_six)
percentage_runs <- (num_run_plays / total_third_and_six) * 100




Code
avg_yards_runs <- mean(run_plays$yards_gained)




Code
runs_by_team_year <- third_and_six |> 
  filter(play_type == "Rush") |> 
  group_by(year, pos_team) |> 
  summarise(run_plays = n()) |> 
  arrange(year, desc(run_plays))


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'year'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.




Code
most_runs_by_team <- runs_by_team_year |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |> 
  summarise(total_runs = sum(run_plays)) |> 
  arrange(desc(total_runs)) |> 
  slice(1)

total_runs_by_year <- runs_by_team_year  |> 
  group_by(year) |> 
  summarize(total_runs = sum(run_plays))




Code
maryland_third_and_six <- third_and_six |> 
  filter(pos_team == "Maryland")

maryland_runs <- maryland_third_and_six |> 
  filter(play_type == "Rush")

num_maryland_runs <- nrow(maryland_runs)
total_maryland_third_and_six <- nrow(maryland_third_and_six)
percentage_maryland_runs <- (num_maryland_runs / total_maryland_third_and_six) *100
avg_yards_maryland_runs <- mean(maryland_runs$yards_gained)




Code
total_maryland_runs <- sum(maryland_runs$rush)

head(maryland_runs)

Code
top_teams <- runs_by_team_year |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |> 
  summarise(total = sum(run_plays)) |> 
  arrange(desc(total)) |> 
  head(10) |> 
  pull(pos_team)




Code
runs_chart_data <- runs_by_team_year |> 
  filter(pos_team %in% top_teams)




Code
ggplot(runs_chart_data, aes(x = reorder(pos_team, -run_plays), y = run_plays, fill = as.factor(year))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(
    title = "Runs on 3rd and 6 by Top Teams (2021–2025)",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Number of Runs",
    fill = "Year"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()









Reading the Graph: Teams like Florida State, Ole Miss, Michigan, UNLV, New Mexico, Baylor, West Virginia, Air Force, Navy, and Army are listed on the y axis. The x axis represents the number of runs on 3rd and 6 plays, and each color represents a year. Army has shown to have the highest number of runs in 2021, with over 15 runs. Baylor has also had a standout year in 2021 with 13-14 runs. Navy (2022) and Air Force (2023) show high counts around 13. Most teams fluctuate totals from year to year, reflecting new play calling trends. Lastly, Florida State, Ole Miss, and Michigan have lower totals compared to other schools. Across 2021-2025, there were over 16,000 3rd and 6 plays in college football. The most common play types were passes, runs, and few punts along woth other calls like field goals and sacks.
Teams ran the ball over 3,000 times on 3rd and 6, making up about 25% of plays. The average yards gained on these runs was just 2.8, failing to convert. This would suggest that teams use runs to set up a succesful 4th down.
Running on 3rd and 6 isn’t ideal. But some teams take advantage of it more than others. From the data, the top runners include service academies like Army (16 in 2021), Air Force (12 in 2023), and Navy (16 in 2022), along with teams like Baylor (16 in 2021), and UNLV (9 in 2022 and 2024). These teams ran the ball frequenty and this could be because of other options or heavy running plays.
Runs peaked in 2024 with 829 run plays and dropped in 2025 with 487 total running plays, possibly due to changing strategies or rules.
Army leads the group with 44 total runs accross the seasons, followed by Navy and Airforce. Powerhouse offenses with strong rushing players tend to run more, while pass heavy teams like Cleamson run less frequently.
Maryland has had 75 total 3rd and 6 plays from 2021-2025. They ran 15 17 times and gained 2.5 yards. Maryland had 4 run plays in 2021, 6 in 2022, 4 in 2023, 2 in 2024, and 1 in 2025. They have shown a clear downward trend since 2021, with fewer runs in recent years. Maryland’s game has changed and they have become more conservative, more likely passing or punting more to avoid the risk of a loss like the Washington game.
Overall, running on 3rd and 6 is a risky, low reward play that can pay off or also lead to worse. Teams like Army, Navy, and Air Force run it most, while Maryland has dialed it back since 2021.
